quiz.title: AP Physics C: Mechanics
quiz.subtitle: Unit 3, Quiz 2: Work by Constant Force (Advanced Applications)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Work as a dot product, Power-time integration, Closed-loop work, Path independence of conservative forces, 3D applications

questions.question: A particle moves from $\vec{r}_i = 2\hat{i} - 3\hat{j}$ m to $\vec{r}_f = -1\hat{i} + 5\hat{j}$ m under a constant force $\vec{F} = 10\hat{i} + 2\hat{j}$ N. Calculate the work done.
questions.explanation: First, find displacement: $\Delta \vec{r} = \vec{r}_f - \vec{r}_i = (-1 - 2)\hat{i} + (5 - (-3))\hat{j} = -3\hat{i} + 8\hat{j}$. Then compute the dot product: $W = \vec{F} \cdot \Delta \vec{r} = (10)(-3) + (2)(8) = -30 + 16 = -14$ J. Negative work means the force opposes the direction of motion on net.

questions.question: The power delivered to an object is $P(t) = 4t + 2$ Watts. Find the work done by the force from $t = 0$ to $t = 3$ seconds.
questions.explanation: Work is the time-integral of power: $W = \int_{0}^{3} P(t) dt = \int_{0}^{3} (4t + 2) dt$. The antiderivative is $2t^2 + 2t$. Evaluating from 0 to 3: $[2(3)^2 + 2(3)] - 0 = 18 + 6 = 24$ J.

questions.question: An object moves along the y-axis from $y = 0$ to $y = 10$ m. A constant force $\vec{F} = 6\hat{i} - 8\hat{j}$ N acts on it. What is the work done?
questions.explanation: The displacement vector is purely in the y-direction: $\Delta \vec{r} = 0\hat{i} + 10\hat{j}$. Work is $W = \vec{F} \cdot \Delta \vec{r} = (6)(0) + (-8)(10) = -80$ J. Only the y-component of the force does work since displacement is purely vertical.

questions.question: For a constant force $\vec{F} = \vec{C}$, which of the following describes the work done over a closed loop path?
options: $W$ depends on the area of the loop.
$W$ is non-zero if the loop is non-circular.
questions.explanation: For a constant force, work is path-independent. Over a closed loop, the net displacement is zero, so $\oint d\vec{r} = 0$. Thus, $W = \vec{C} \cdot \oint d\vec{r} = \vec{C} \cdot 0 = 0$. This confirms that a constant force is conservative.

questions.question: A constant force $\vec{F}$ acts on a mass $m$ moving it from A to B. If the same force acts on a mass $2m$ moving it along the same path, the work done is:
questions.explanation: Work is defined by $W = \vec{F} \cdot \Delta \vec{r}$. It depends only on the force and the displacement, not on the mass of the object. The mass affects acceleration and kinetic energy change, but the work performed by the given force $\vec{F}$ remains the same.

questions.question: A particle's velocity is $\vec{v}(t) = 3\hat{i} - 2t\hat{j}$ m/s. A constant force $\vec{F} = 4\hat{i}$ N acts on it. Find the Power at $t = 5$ s.
A constant force $\vec{F} = 5\hat{k}$ N acts on an object moving along $\vec{r}(t) = t^2\hat{i} + 2t\hat{j} + 5\hat{k}$ from $t=0$ to $t=4$. Find $W$.
questions.explanation: The z-component of the position is constant ($z=5$), so $\Delta z = 0$. The force has only a $\hat{k}$ component, so $W = F_z \Delta z = (5)(0) = 0$ J. Even though the object moves in x and y, the force is perpendicular to that motion, so it does no work.

questions.question: If a constant force $\vec{F}$ is conservative, the work done $W = \int_{A}^{B} \vec{F} \cdot d\vec{r}$ is:
questions.explanation: By definition, a conservative force is one for which the work done in moving between two points is independent of the path taken. Constant forces satisfy this property because $\vec{F} \cdot \Delta \vec{r}$ depends only on the endpoints.

questions.question: A constant force $\vec{F} = \langle F_x, F_y \rangle$ acts on an object. The work done is $W = F_x \Delta x + F_y \Delta y$. This is an application of:
questions.explanation: The dot product (scalar product) of two vectors $\vec{A} \cdot \vec{B}$ is defined as $A_x B_x + A_y B_y + A_z B_z$. Here, $W = \vec{F} \cdot \Delta \vec{r}$ follows this exact form.

questions.question: A particle moves from $(0,0)$ to $(3,4)$ m while a constant force $\vec{F} = -3\hat{i} - 4\hat{j}$ N acts on it. The work done is:
questions.explanation: Displacement $\Delta \vec{r} = 3\hat{i} + 4\hat{j}$. Work $W = \vec{F} \cdot \Delta \vec{r} = (-3)(3) + (-4)(4) = -9 - 16 = -25$ J. The force is directed opposite to the displacement, resulting in negative work.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of constant force work concepts in 2D/3D. You can handle negative work, power integration, closed-loop properties, and understand that work depends only on force and displacement, not mass.
scoreMessages.70: Strong analytical skills. Review the physical meaning of negative work and the fact that force components perpendicular to displacement do zero work. Also, ensure comfort with $W = \int P(t) dt$.
scoreMessages.50: Good foundation. Focus on: calculating displacement correctly in vector form, applying the dot product accurately, and remembering that work for constant forces is path-independent.
scoreMessages.0: Start with the basic definition $W = Fd\cos\theta$ for straight-line motion. Practice vector subtraction to find displacement, and compute simple dot products before moving to power integration.
